ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Typing fast in Hebrew and Hebrew writing skills as well as knowledge on issues in israel
My Hebrew writing skills improved dramatically in this course and my speaking improved somewhat in class discussions.

Improved Hebrew vocabulary and writing skills, stronger understanding of Israeli pre-state history, and multiple issues throughout the past century. I have a pretty strong understanding of the current Israeli political situation and how it ended up there, and more specific in-depth knowledge of a few topics that I chose to focus my writing or projects on.
I learned a lot about contemporary Israeli politics and improved my written and oral language skills in the process.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - lots of time to converse with others in Hebrew

I think the course could be improved if its workload were lowered slightly and if it were made clear that it is a higher-level L5 than the others in the Hebrew department. That said, I think it is a great course.
The conversations between students can be really interesting and exciting, and we cover a pretty interesting breadth of content.

Strengths: the material is very engaging and I felt like my Hebrew, especially my level of writing, improved very fast.
Weakness: the workload was quite heavy. If you take the assignments seriously, you will spend 4+ hours per assignment sometimes.
While I think improving one's writing skills is important, I feel like there were sometimes too many questions and it was almost impossible to do the homework justice while staying within the word limit.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want an immersive Hebrew experience then yes

Yes, I would recommend this course. I would only recommend it to a student who has significant Hebrew skills and is interested in discussing contemporary issues in Israel, but if the student did meet these criteria I would certainly recommend it.

Yes, but know that it's a lot of work if you are not a totally fluent Hebrew writer. 250 words per class (twice a week), in addition to occasional projects and presentations. That being said, it's a challenging, rewarding class that can be genuinely fun if you make an effort from the beginning to get to know and appreciate the other students in the class and their personal relationships to the issues at hand (make a whatsapp group asap!) and if you bring the ideas that you're interested in into the class (Professor Roginsky is very encouraging of this). If you want to feel solid talking about Israeli politics and social issues in both Hebrew and English, this is a great class, but be prepared to think very critically and to dissect these issues with nuance.
Yes, I would if you are an advanced Hebrew speaker who is interested in the history of Zionism, Israeli history and modern Israeli politics.
